entry.title: Re: Error during copy of partner: Partner role SH
entry.content:
Hello @AngelT 

Thank you for your follow up and the screenshots,they have been so helpful

Thanks for the screenshots; they have been helpful. Here is what I can see and what is probably still missing.

What appears satisfactory

  • The assignment between Plant 05DB and Sales Org 10DB exists (CBC screen).
  • The shipping point determination for 05DB suggests 51PB looks good.
  • The BP 10401040 functions as both Supplier FLVN01 and Customer FLCU01 – Company Code, and supplier/customer cross-links are established is good.

What’s probably missing ,the usual obstacle

You have shown FLCU01 Customer – Company Code, but 4SD/SD partner determination uses FLCU00 Customer – Sales Area. Without Sales Area data, the Partner Functions tab doesn’t exist, and SH Ship-To cannot be determined.

What you should quickly check

Open BP 10401040 → Role FLCU00 Customer (Sales Area)

Add Sales Area = 10DB / your Distribution Channel/Division must match the plant’s sales organisation assignment.

Navigate to Partner Functions and ensure you have at least:

  • SP Sold-To= This BP
  • SH Ship-To = This BP or a different Ship-To BP if you use an alternative delivery address.
  • Optional BP Bill-To, PY Payer

If Ship-To uses a different address

Either create a dedicated Ship-To Business Partner with that address and assign it as SH in FLCU00 or keep one BP and use its standard address for deliveries. If you need an alternative delivery address for each order, handle it in the sales document.

Sanity Check

  • Please create a quick sales order in Sales Org 10DB for customer 10401040.
  • Review the Partners tab → SH needs to be suggested.
  • If SH is still missing, the partner determination procedure/assignment. The customer account group in Sales Org 10DB requires review.

Why Your Setup Still Fails

A second address on the BP or simply the FLCU01 view does not create the SH partner.

  • Only FLCU00 (Sales Area) and Partner Functions generate the SD SH role that the system looks for.

Let me know if it works

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Value Help in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition always resets and shows all entries
entry.content:
Hi all,

We are using S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

As shown in the attached screenshot, whenever I open a value help (for example, on customer or vendor fields), the dialog always resets and displays the full list of entries.

This is problematic in customer demos because we do not want to expose test or irrelevant master data.
Ideally, I would like to:
- Keep the last-used filter criteria when reopening the value help, or
- Apply a predefined default filter (e.g., Country = JP) automatically when opening the dialog.

So far I have tried:
- Personal Value List → lets me mark favorite values, but does not preserve filter conditions
- “Default Values” in Fiori Settings → works for global fields like company code, but not inside value help filters
- Variants → not available in certain apps (e.g., Invoice Summarization / Periodic Billing)

**My questions:**
1. Is there any standard way in Public Cloud to persist or predefine filter criteria in the value help dialog?
2. If not, should I understand this behavior as a system limitation by design?
3. How do other companies typically handle this in demos or daily operations when the value help contains many entries?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Driving AI Adoption with BTP: Highlights
entry.content:
A couple of days ago,  AI experts and SAP customers gathered at SAP AI Adoption Event in Barcelona to explore how Artificial Intelligence is reshaping business.

There we innovate with a fresh format designed to maximize both learning and practical engagement. The morning featured plenary sessions, where SAP leaders and experts shared the latest insights on how AI is transforming business. In the afternoon, participants had the opportunity to go deeper—joining hands-on workshops and 1:1 discussions with dedicated SAP experts to explore solutions tailored to their unique challenges.

The mix of high-level perspectives and practical deep dives created an environment where strategy met execution, ensuring that every attendee left not just inspired, but equipped with actionable next steps.

Why AI Now - and Why SAP?

AI is no longer experimental—it’s driving real business outcomes. Organizations need AI to boost efficiency, turn data into actionable insights, and respond proactively to changing business conditions. SAP’s Business AI helps companies act faster and smarter across every function.

SAP stands out because AI is embedded in core business processes, powered by trusted, unified data, and designed for scalability and customization. This ensures reliable insights, faster decisions, and measurable impact at enterprise scale.

Why it matters?

AI adoption today determines competitive advantage. Companies that leverage AI effectively can accelerate growth, improve customer experiences, optimize operations, and achieve sustainability goals—while those that wait risk falling behind.

 

Agenda Highlights & Session recap

Welcome & Introduction

Speaker: Marc Nolla

  • Set the stage with SAP’s strategic push on Artificial Intelligence
  • Challenge: What AI competitive advantage are you going to Build?

Link to presentation

Exploring the Potential of SAP BTP AI 

Speaker: Daniil Bolobonov & Marco Holzwarth

  • Explanation of our enterprise AI offering that integrates easily with your SAP systems (and also non-SAP!) to help you work smarter.
  • Architecture perspective of Joule extensibility and AI Foundation 

Link to presentation

AI Best Practices with SAP

Speaker: Alex Dalentzas

  • AI Evolution since 2016
  • Some learnings on how you can apply AI to your business processes
  • Autonomous ERP: a real case scenario
  • The relevance on an AI Architect

Link to presentation

SAP AI Portfolio and What's New

Speaker: Arthur Liebhardt

  • Sneak peek on the lastest innovations on Joule 
  • Joule Agents as the next era of business automation
  • Live demo of Generative AI Hub and Vibe Coding

Link to presentation

Hands-On Workshops

  • Four breakout room SAP BTP AI topics: 
    • Retrieval-Augmented Generation with SAP HANA Cloud
    • Automated Business Document proccessing with SAP Document AI
    • From Automation to Intelligent Business Conversations with Joule Studio
    • AI capabilities in Data and Analytics
  • Interaction with many customers and discussion on particular use cases
  • Opportunity to gain the digital badges for the hands-on
  • The portal for hands-on will be open until 2nd October 2025 for you to finish the exercises

For inquiries, please reach out to SAP BTP Adoption Workshop team: sap_btp_adoption_workshop@sap.com 

Closing Notes / Adoption and Next Steps

 Speaker: Ana Lopera

  • How to engage with your BTP CSM and move forward
  • SAP initiatives to support the AI and how can we help you to achieve it

Key Takeaways

  1. AI is delivering real business value today 
  2. Trusted, business-ready AI is essential
  3. SAP’s differentiator is integration at scale 
  4. Collaboration accelerates innovation 
  5. Act now or risk falling behind 

What’s Next?

Here’s how to keep the momentum going:

entry.title: Alternative Account Change Blocked in S/4HANA Cloud Public - French Legal Requirement
entry.content:
System: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Finance
Component: FI-FIO-GL-MD (G/L Master Data)
Country: France

Business Context

Due to recent changes in French accounting law, we need to urgently modify alternative account assignments for several G/L accounts in our French Chart of Accounts. This is a mandatory legal requirement for fiscal year 2025.

Technical Issue

When attempting to change alternative accounts for Fixed Asset-related G/L accounts (e.g., accounts in class 675 - Net book value of disposed assets, class 775 - Proceeds from asset disposals) under our French company codes, we receive the error:

"Changes not possible since account balance is not zero"

Current situation:

  • 2025 balances: Zero ✓
  • 2024 balances: Non-zero (causing the block)
  • 2023 balances: Unknown

Business Constraint

We cannot clear the 2024 balances because:

  • The fiscal year 2024 audit is completed and closed
  • Any modification to historical balances would violate audit compliance
  • These are Fixed Asset accounts (CORE accounts) with automatic postings from asset transactions

What We've Tried

  1. Opened SAP incident 
  2. SAP Support confirmed this is standard system behavior - requires zero balance for the last 2 fiscal years
  3. SAP suggested creating new G/L accounts as a workaround
  4. Business team escalated as this doesn't meet the legal requirement

Our Question

Has anyone faced a similar situation where legal/regulatory changes require alternative account modifications on Fixed Asset accounts with historical balances?

Specifically looking for:

  • Any SAP notes addressing this scenario
  • Possible exemption procedures for legal requirements
  • Alternative solutions that maintain audit compliance
  • Experience with similar French accounting law changes

This is blocking our legal compliance for 2025. Any insights would be greatly appreciated.

Tags: #S4HANA-Cloud ##GL-Master-Data #French-Accounting #Legal-Compliance #Alternative-Account #Fixed-Asset

entry.title: Advanced Intercompany Sales in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Advanced Intercompany Sales in SAP S/4HANA

Version: 1.0

 

1. Introduction to Advanced Intercompany Sales

 

1.1 What is the Purpose?

In a global business environment, it's common for one part of a company to sell a product to an external customer, while another affiliated company, perhaps in a different country, is responsible for manufacturing and/or delivering it. The Advanced Intercompany Sales process is designed to manage these complex, cross-company transactions seamlessly and efficiently.

A key feature of this process is the creation of an additional purchase order in the selling company and a corresponding sales order in the delivering company, automating the internal procurement and sales activities. This process uses

Valuated Stock in Transit (VSIT), which is crucial for maintaining clear financial visibility and control of inventory as it moves between affiliated companies and ultimately to the customer.

1.2 Key Benefits and Capabilities

The Advanced Intercompany Sales process in S/4HANA provides significant advantages:

  • Enhanced Profitability Reporting: It allows for accurate profitability analysis for both the selling and delivering affiliated companies.
  • Seamless Transfer of Control: Manages the clear and precise transfer of inventory ownership between the affiliates and the final customer.
  • Event-Based Revenue Recognition: Enables revenue to be recognized at the correct time based on specific events in the sales cycle, ensuring compliance and accurate financial statements.
  • Detailed Costing: Integrates with the material ledger and provides a cost component split, offering deep insight into product costs.
  • Integrated Compliance: Incorporates product and trade compliance checks directly into the process flow.
  • Transportation Management: Allows for full integration into transportation management processes, including the calculation and allocation of freight costs.

2. The Business Case Scenario

To understand the process in a practical context, this guide will follow a specific, real-world business scenario based on the pre-configured data in the SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance.

  • The Seller: Sales Organization 1010, located in Germany. This is the entity that has the relationship with the end customer. They belong to
    Selling Company 1010.
  • The Customer: Customer 10100002, a domestic customer also located in Germany.
  • The Supplier/Deliverer: Plant 1710, located in the United States. This plant holds the stock and will ship the goods. It is owned by the
    Delivering Company 1710.
  • The Product: Material TG12, which is a trading good.

The Process Flow at a Glance

  1. The German Sales Organization (1010) receives a purchase order from the German customer (10100002).
  2. A sales order is created in the German company code (1010). However, the delivering plant is specified as the US plant (1710).
  3. The system automatically triggers the creation of an intercompany purchase order in the German company (1010) and an intercompany sales order in the US company (1710).
  4. The US plant (1710) ships the goods directly to the German customer.
  5. The goods are temporarily held in Valuated Stock in Transit (VSIT), which is owned by the selling company (1010) but managed within their plant (1010).
  6. The US company (1710) sends an intercompany invoice to the German company (1010) for the goods.
  7. The German company (1010) sends the final customer invoice to the German customer (10100002).

This structure ensures that both legal entities (US and German companies) have the correct accounting and logistical documents to reflect the transaction accurately.

3. Prerequisites and Initial Setup

Before executing the test plan, it's essential to ensure the system is properly set up. This section covers the required system access, user roles, master data, and other necessary configurations.

3.1 System Access and User Roles

  • System: This guide is designed for an SAP S/4HANA 2023 Fully-Activated Appliance. Access is typically via the SAP Fiori launchpad.
  • Demo User: You can use the standard demo user provided with the appliance:
    • User: S4H_SD_DEM
    • Password: Welcome1
  • Business Roles: The end-to-end process involves several business roles. The
    S4H_SD_DEM user is pre-assigned the necessary roles, which include:
    • Internal Sales Representative
    • Shipping Specialist
    • Billing Clerk
    • Accounts Payable Accountant
    • Inventory Manager

3.2 Master and Organizational Data

The following master and organizational data are pre-configured in the appliance and will be used throughout the exercises. Using your own data is possible, but this sample data is recommended for following the guide.

Key Master Data

Data Type

Value

Details and Role in the Process

Material

TG12

The trading good being sold to the customer.

Customer

10100002

The end customer in Germany who buys the product.

Intercompany Payer

10401010

From the US Delivering Company's perspective, this represents the German Selling Company as a customer. It's the payer in the intercompany invoice.

Intercompany Supplier

17401710

From the German Selling Company's perspective, this represents the US Delivering Company as a vendor. It's the invoicing party for the intercompany supplier invoice.

Intercompany Plant Customer

10411010

From the US Delivering Company's perspective, this represents the German plant (1010) as a customer (the sold-to party) in the intercompany sales order.

Intercompany Plant Supplier

BP1710

From the German Selling Company's perspective, this represents the US plant (1710) as a vendor in the automatically created purchase order.

Export to Sheets

Key Organizational Data

Data Type

Value

Details

Selling Co.'s Sales Org

1010

The sales organization in the German selling company.

Delivering Co.'s Sales Org

1710

The sales organization in the US delivering company.

Distribution Channel

10

Direct Sales channel.

Division

00

General product division.

Export to Sheets

3.3 How to Create New Master Data

While this guide uses pre-existing data, in a real project, you would need to create it. For detailed instructions on creating master data objects, refer to the

SAP Best Practices for SAP S/4HANA Master Data Scripts (MDS).

Master Data ID

Description

BND

Create Customer Master

BNE

Create Supplier Master

BNF

Create Product Master of Type "Trading Good"

Export to Sheets

3.4 System Preparation

Before you begin, ensure the following preparatory steps are completed:

  1. Open MM Posting Periods: The material management posting periods must be open for the current month in both company codes (1010 and 1710). This is a standard periodic task required for any goods movement. This is detailed in the post-deployment steps for the appliance.
  2. (Optional) Procure Material TG12: If you run out of stock for material TG12 in the delivering plant (1710), you can add more using the Manage Stock (F1062) Fiori app or transaction MIGO.
  3. (Optional) Create Condition Records: If pricing has been customized, you may need to create sales pricing condition records to ensure prices are determined correctly in the sales and billing documents. This is done using the procedures in the "Create Sales Pricing Condition" Master Data Script.

4. Consultant's Corner: Customizing Insights

This guide is based on a pre-configured, fully-activated appliance where all necessary customizing is already complete. However, for consultants implementing this solution, understanding the configuration backbone is critical. Below are the conceptual areas in SPRO (or via CBC for cloud) that underpin the Advanced Intercompany Sales process.

  • Enterprise Structure (Assignment): The fundamental assignments must be in place.
    • Assign Plant (1710) to Company Code (1710).
    • Assign Sales Organization (1010, 1710) to Company Code (1010, 1710).
    • Set up the sales areas (Sales Org / Dist. Channel / Division).
  • Sales and Distribution:
    • Sales Document Type: The customer sales order type (OR in this demo) needs to be configured to allow this process. Key settings are often in the item category determination.
    • Item Category: The item category determined for material TG12 in the sales order is crucial. It must be configured to trigger the creation of an intercompany purchase requisition and subsequent purchase order.
    • Partner Determination: Procedures must be set up to correctly determine the intercompany partners (e.g., the intercompany supplier and customer) in the sales and purchasing documents.
    • Billing: The intercompany billing type (IV2) and the customer billing type (F2) must be configured with the correct settings for pricing, account determination, and posting rules.
  • Materials Management:
    • Purchase Order Document Type: A specific document type for the automatic intercompany PO is required.
    • Valuated Stock in Transit: Configuration for VSIT is essential. This involves setting up the stock-in-transit valuation and the specific movement types that post goods into and out of SIT.
  • Financial Accounting:
    • Automatic Account Determination (OBYC/VKOA): This is critical for ensuring all goods movements and billing documents post to the correct G/L accounts automatically. This includes accounts for revenue, cost of goods sold, receivables, payables, and inventory.

Executing this process successfully relies on the tight integration and correct configuration of these SD, MM, and FI components.

5. End-to-End Process Walkthrough & Test Plan

This section provides a detailed, step-by-step guide to execute the Advanced Intercompany Sales process. It is structured as a practical, hands-on test plan that you can follow in your system.

Overall Process Flow Overview

Step #

Process Step

Business Role

Fiori App / Transaction

1

Create Sales Order

Internal Sales Rep

Manage Sales Orders (F1873)

2

Display Intercompany PO

Internal Sales Rep

Monitor Value Chains (F4854)

3

Display Intercompany SO

Internal Sales Rep

Monitor Value Chains (F4854)

4

Create Delivery

Shipping Specialist

Create Outbound Deliveries (F0869A)

5

Perform Picking

Shipping Specialist

Manage Outbound Deliveries (F0867A)

6

Post Goods Issue

Shipping Specialist

Manage Outbound Deliveries (F0867A)

7

Confirm Transfer of Control

Shipping Specialist

Manage Outbound Deliveries (F0867A)

8

Create Intercompany Invoice

Billing Clerk

Create Billing Documents (F0798)

9

Display Intercompany Supplier Invoice

Accounts Payable Accountant

Supplier Invoices List (F1060a)

10

Create Customer Invoice

Billing Clerk

Create Billing Documents (F0798)

11

Monitor Value Chain

Internal Sales Rep

Monitor Value Chains (F4854)

Export to Sheets

Test Case 1: Execute the Advanced Intercompany Sales Flow

Objective: To create a customer sales order in the selling company that is delivered by an affiliated company, and to process all subsequent logistical and financial documents correctly.

Step 1: Create Sales Order (Selling Company)

Objective: The process starts when the selling company creates a sales order for the external customer, but specifies that the goods will be delivered from an affiliate's plant.

  • Role: Internal Sales Representative
  • App: Manage Sales Orders (F1873)

Execution Steps:

  1. Log on to the Fiori launchpad as user
    S4H_SD_DEM.
  2. Navigate to the
    Sales section and open the Manage Sales Orders app.
  3. Click
    Create Sales Order.
  4. Enter the following organizational data and press Enter :
    • Order Type: OR
    • Sales Organization: 1010
    • Distribution Channel: 10
    • Division: 00
  5. On the
    Create Standard Order: Overview screen, enter the following header and item data :
    • Sold-to Party: 10100002
    • Cust. Reference: PO-INTERCOMPANY-TEST
    • Deliver. Plant: 1710 (This is the critical step: specifying the US affiliate plant).
    • Material: TG12
    • Order Quantity: 10
  6. Go to the item details by selecting the item and navigating to the
    Shipping tab.
  7. Fill in the following field:
    • Transit Plant: 1010. This plant represents the selling company's ownership of the stock while it is in transit.
  8. Click
    Save.

Expected Result: A standard sales order is created in the selling company (1010). Note down the Sales Order Number. The system automatically triggers the creation of an intercompany purchase order in company 1010 and an intercompany sales order in company 1710 in the background.

Step 2: Display Intercompany Purchase Order

Objective: To confirm that the system automatically created an intercompany purchase order in the selling company to procure the goods from the delivering company.

  • Role: Internal Sales Representative
  • App: Monitor Value Chains (F4854)

Execution Steps:

  1. From the Fiori launchpad, open the
    Monitor Value Chains app.
  2. In the filter bar, enter the following:
    • Initiating Document: Your Sales Order number from Step 1.
    • Process Type: Advanced Intercompany Sales
  3. Click Go.
  4. Click on the line item that appears in the
    Business Processes list.
  5. In the
    Documents list, locate the step "IC Purchase Order (POIC)".
  6. Click on the document number link to display the intercompany purchase order.

Expected Result: The system displays the intercompany purchase order created in the selling company (1010) with the delivering plant (1710) as the vendor. Note down the

Purchase Order Number.

Step 3: Display Intercompany Sales Order

Objective: To confirm the creation of the corresponding intercompany sales order in the delivering company.

  • Role: Internal Sales Representative
  • App: Monitor Value Chains (F4854)

Execution Steps:

  1. Return to the Monitor Value Chains screen for your sales order.
  2. In the
    Documents list, locate the step "IC Sales Order (SOIC)".
  3. Click on the document number link to display the intercompany sales order .

Expected Result: The system displays the intercompany sales order created in the delivering company (1710). The sold-to party will be the intercompany customer representing the selling company (e.g.,

10411010). Note down the

Intercompany Sales Order Number.

Step 4: Create Delivery (Delivering Company)

Objective: The delivering company now creates an outbound delivery to ship the goods directly to the end customer.

  • Role: Shipping Specialist
  • App: Create Outbound Deliveries - From Sales Orders (F0869A)

Execution Steps:

  1. Open the
    Create Outbound Deliveries - From Sales Orders app.
  2. Enter the following selection criteria and click
    Go :
    • Shipping Point: 1710
    • Order: Your original sales order number from Step 1.
  3. Select the sales order item from the list and click
    Create Deliveries .

Expected Result: An outbound delivery document is created successfully. Note down the

Delivery Number.

Step 5: Perform Picking

Objective: To pick the goods from the storage location in preparation for shipping.

  • Role: Shipping Specialist
  • App: Manage Outbound Deliveries (F0867A) or My Outbound Delivery Monitor (VL06O)

Execution Steps:

  1. Open the
    My Outbound Delivery Monitor (VL06O) app.
  2. Click on
    For Picking.
  3. Enter your Shipping Point (
    1710) and press Execute.
  4. Select your delivery document and choose
    Change Outbound Deliveries.
  5. Navigate to the
    Picking tab.
  6. Enter the delivery quantity (e.g.,
    10) in the Picked Qty field.
  7. Click
    Save.

Expected Result: The picking status of the delivery is updated to "Fully Picked". The delivery document is saved.

Step 6: Post Goods Issue (PGI)

Objective: To post the goods issue, which signifies that the goods have left the delivering plant. This transaction transfers the material into Valuated Stock in Transit.

  • Role: Shipping Specialist
  • App: My Outbound Delivery Monitor (VL06O)

Execution Steps:

  1. Open the
    My Outbound Delivery Monitor (VL06O) app.
  2. Click on
    For Goods Issue.
  3. Enter your Shipping Point (
    1710) and press Execute.
  4. Select your delivery document and click the
    Post Goods Issue button.
  5. Confirm the posting date in the dialog box and click
    Continue.

Expected Result: The goods issue is posted successfully. The inventory in plant 1710 is reduced. The ownership of the goods is transferred to the selling company (1010) and is now reflected as

Stock in Transit. The follow-on goods movements are scheduled based on the Transfer of Control dates.

Step 7: Confirm Transfer of Control (ToC) Dates

Objective: To confirm the dates when the control of goods transfers between affiliates (internal) and from the selling company to the customer (external). This is a critical step that triggers further financial postings.

  • Role: Shipping Specialist
  • App: Outbound Delivery Monitor or directly change the outbound delivery.

Execution Steps:

  1. Find and open your outbound delivery in change mode.
  2. From the top menu, navigate via:
    More > Goto > Header > Shipment.
  3. In the
    Internal Transfer of Control Dates section, update the Actual Date and Time to the current system date and time. This controls the posting from the delivering company's SIT to the selling company's SIT.
  4. In the
    External Transfer of Control Dates section, update the Actual Date and Time to the current system date and time. This controls the final goods issue from the selling company's SIT to the customer (representing the COGS posting).
  5. Click Save.

Expected Result: The Transfer of Control dates are confirmed. The system executes the following goods movements and financial postings in the background :

  • Post Goods Issue from SiT in delivering company: COGS is posted for the delivering company.
  • Post Goods Receipt to selling company: Inventory is received into the selling company's books.
  • Post Stock Transfer to SiT in selling company: Inventory is moved to the selling company's SIT.
  • Post Goods Issue from SiT to Customer: COGS is posted for the selling company.

Step 8: Create Intercompany Invoice

Objective: The delivering company (1710) bills the selling company (1010) for the goods provided.

  • Role: Billing Clerk
  • App: Create Billing Documents (F0798)

Execution Steps:

  1. Open the
    Create Billing Documents app.
  2. In the search area, enter your
    Delivery Number and press Enter.
  3. Select the row for your delivery and click the
    Create Billing Documents button.
  4. A dialog box appears. Choose the following and click
    OK:
    • Billing Type: IV2 (Intercompany Invoice)
    • Billing Date: Current date
  5. The system will display a draft billing document. Review it and click
    Save.

Expected Result: An intercompany invoice (type IV2) is created and posted in company 1710. The system automatically triggers the creation of the corresponding intercompany supplier invoice in company 1010. Note down the

Intercompany Invoice Number.

Step 9: Display Intercompany Supplier Invoice

Objective: To confirm that the supplier invoice was automatically received and created in the selling company's system.

  • Role: Accounts Payable Accountant
  • App: Monitor Value Chains (F4854) or Supplier Invoices List (F1060a)

Execution Steps:

  1. Navigate back to the Monitor Value Chains app and refresh the view for your sales order.
  2. Locate the document for the step
    "IC Supplier Invoice (SIIC)" and click the link to display it.
  3. Alternatively, open the
    Supplier Invoices List app and search for the document using the intercompany invoice number in the Reference field.

Expected Result: The intercompany supplier invoice is displayed in the selling company's system. The vendor will be the intercompany supplier representing the delivering company (e.g.,

17401710).

Step 10: Create Customer Invoice

Objective: The final step is for the selling company (1010) to create the invoice for the end customer.

  • Role: Billing Clerk
  • App: Create Billing Documents (F0798)

Execution Steps:

  1. Open the
    Create Billing Documents app.
  2. Enter your
    Delivery Number in the search area and press Enter.
  3. Select the row for your delivery and click the
    Create Billing Documents button.
  4. In the dialog box, choose the following and click
    OK:
    • Billing Type: F2 (Invoice)
    • Billing Date: Current date
  5. Review the draft invoice and click
    Save.

Expected Result: The final customer invoice (type F2) is created and posted. The accounts receivable and revenue accounts are updated in the selling company's books. Note down the Customer Invoice Number.

Step 11: Monitor the Completed Value Chain

Objective: To review the entire end-to-end process flow and see the status of all linked documents in one place.

  • Role: Internal Sales Representative
  • App: Monitor Value Chains (F4854)

Execution Steps:

  1. Open the
    Monitor Value Chains app.
  2. Search for your initiating
    Sales Order Number.
  3. The system will display the value chain. All steps should now show a
    Completed status.
  4. Click on the
    Process Flow tab to see a graphical representation of the document flow. Each node in the flow chart represents a step and contains details like the document number and status .

Expected Result: The value chain monitor displays a complete, end-to-end flow chart of the process, with all documents linked and showing a completed (green) status. This provides a perfect audit trail of the entire transaction.

6. Summary

This guide has walked you through the Advanced Intercompany Sales process in SAP S/4HANA, from the initial customer order to the final invoicing and monitoring. By leveraging this functionality, organizations can manage complex internal supply chains with greater efficiency, transparency, and financial control. Following the business case and test plan provides a solid, practical understanding of how to execute and manage these transactions in a modern SAP environment.

entry.title: Re: Purchase order Percentage Price Condition on Purchase...
entry.content: Hi @Phil_P, When you post percentage based custom conditions through the SOAP API_SAP_COM_0238, the API schema enforces that you send a ConditionQuantitiy and unitCode, even though logically they are not required for percentage conditions. The correct way is for you to: • Pass the % in <ConditionRateValue> • Keep the <ConditionQuantity> as 1 with a neutral UoM such as the item’s base UoM • Ensure your condition type is configured in pricing with Calculation Type=A (Percentage) As mentioned earlier, this will create a 10% condition. Using % as unitCode is not supported, which explains why your system shows 0.00. Best regards Chris

entry.title: Replicating IT0006 to SAP ECP with a fixed address value, excluding address information in SF EC
entry.content:
Requirement:  A customer has requested that employee address data be replicated to SAP ECP using a fixed value for all employees. This is because SAP ECP does not require valid individual addresses. IT0006 is only used for payroll processing, and the customer does not utilize address data in IT0006 for any other business purpose.

To fulfill the above requirement, we configured Point-to-Point (PTP) replication as follows:

We removed the address_information query segment from the Compound Employee API Query Configuration under the Point-to-Point Replication settings in the SPRO node (as shown below). This effectively disables the retrieval of address data from SuccessFactors Employee Central during replication.

To enable replication of IT0006, we added it to the Infotype Filter configuration, thereby ensuring it is included in the scope of Point-to-Point replication processing.

Next, we need to populate fixed address data for IT0006.
To achieve this, we implement the BAdI HRSFEC_B_CE_PROCESS_ET under the Business Add-Ins for Point-to-Point Replication, as shown below. This enhancement allows us to inject constant address values during the replication process, bypassing address data from SuccessFactors Employee Central.

Below is a sample code snippet demonstrating the approach:

* Declarations
DATA: lt_pnnnn        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF p0006 WITH DEFAULT KEY,
      lt_node_names   TYPE if_hrsfec_ce_purge_details=>tt_node_name,
      lv_employment_id TYPE hrsfec_employment_id,
      lt_p0006        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF p0006 WITH DEFAULT KEY,
      wa_p0006        TYPE p0006.

* Register processed node for message handling
CALL METHOD io_message_handler->register_processed_node
  EXPORTING iv_processed_node = cl_hrsfec_service_lib=>gc_node_workagreement_item.

* Convert employment ID
lv_employment_id = is_employment_information-employment_id.

* Append relevant CE API segment
APPEND if_hrsfec_api_ce_data=>gc_segment-job_information TO lt_node_names.

* Check for data purge
IF io_hrsfec_ce_purge_details->is_purge_date_after_ftsd(
     iv_personnel_number = iv_personnel_number
     iv_employment_id    = lv_employment_id
     it_node_name        = lt_node_names
     iv_infty            = gc_infotype-infty_nnnn
     iv_badi_name        = 'HRSFEC_B_CE_PROCESS_ET' ) EQ abap_true.

  RETURN. "Abort processing to avoid unintended deletions

ENDIF.

* Populate fixed address data
  wa_p0006-pernr = iv_personnel_number.
  wa_p0006-begda = is_employment_information-start_date.
  wa_p0006-endda = '99991231'.
  wa_p0006-infty = '0006'.
  wa_p0006-subty = '1'.
  wa_p0006-anssa = '1'.
  wa_p0006-ort01 = 'City'.
  wa_p0006-itbld = '24'.
  wa_p0006-land1 = 'SA'.

  APPEND wa_p0006 TO lt_p0006.

* Update infotype framework
CALL METHOD cl_hrsfec_service_lib=>update_mass_pnnnn_data
  EXPORTING
    iv_pernr                  = iv_personnel_number
    iv_infty                  = '0006'
    io_message_handler        = io_message_handler
    io_masterdata_bl          = io_hrpa_masterdata_bl
    it_pnnnn                  = lt_p0006
    iv_full_trans_start_date = iv_full_transmission_start_dat.

entry.title: Re: Real world functional testing for courses in Success...
entry.content:
If this is happening for all users, I would test the lesson in SCORMCloud, there you can see all the logs and trace where the issue is occurring. This is one of our requirements that our designers successfully test in SCORMCloud before having the lessons uploaded to the LMS.

If this is not happening to ALL users, then I would look at individual browser settings. SF requires third-party cookies to be ON. Whereas all modern browsers have them OFF by default. If they are not on, users are booted out of the system after 30 minutes, regardless of if they are in the middle of a lesson or not. This has been our number 1 support ticket with our users for years....

For  testing, we usually make a checklist and/or testing script that the LMS team goes through. The check lists are for things like,

  • due date
  • title
  • is downloadable (we have a lot of users in the app)
  • is mobile enabled
  • marks complete
  • is reviewable
  • etc.

We use testing scripts with course owners when we have a complicated lesson or assessment with branching or question pools to try to ensure all the pathways through the lesson are tested. Otherwise course owners are more responsible for reviewing the content and interaction functionality. The Learning team (learning designers and  LMS admins) are the ones who make sure the course it talking to the LMS correctly.

entry.title: Re: Controller extension changes are not reflecting in Adaptation Project
entry.content:
I am using Visual Studio Code and had a similar problem.

The changes done in the Adaptation Project were not reflected in the preview, after already deploying the project to the target system. That was because fiori-tools-proxy / backend-proxy-middleware and its default configuration in ui5.yaml:

 

Because of that all requests to /sap/bc/lrep/flex are loading changes from the system, instead of your local project:

 

 

You can try to configure the proxy to only load UI5 resources and handle OData communication in following way:

 

I also wrote a post about that on my blog: Why Fiori Adaptation Project local changes are not loaded after deployment?

But I have also included all of the important information here in this reply.

I hope it helps you.

entry.title: Re: USERDIM in FMDERIVE
entry.content:
Hi! What are you trying to achieve? Do you want to fill USERDIM in Funds management document through FMDERIVE?

This is not possible in standard although it actually would make sense to allow this because USERDIM can be used as another account assignment in funds management.

Interesting enough the field is part of structure FMDERIVE which is the source for the source and target fields in FMDERIVE but not available through the search help. Maybe it belongs to some business function to be activated first.

Normally you fill the field USERDIM with two BAdIs depending on the source from which you want to build your derivation logic on. You find these BAdIs in IMG Public Sector Management -> Funds Management Government -> Actual and Commitment Update/Integration -> Integration -> Business Add-Ins (BAdIs)

Target/Actual (BAdI SMOD_SAPLFMRI, Method EXIT_SAPLFMRI_003) provides access to fields from accounting interface ACCIT as the source during runtime.

Fill Customer Fields (FMPU_R_USERDIM) provides access to fields from FMIFIIT as the source during runtime. So you can build your derivation for instance on the already derived fm-account assignments from FMDERIVE.

Do you already use all FM-account assignments? E.g. Measure or functional area? Maybe consider using on of these instead of USERDIM if you want to use FMDERIVE for the derivation.

Otherwise you need to find a way to access values from structure FMDERIVE in one of the mentioned BAdIs during runtime. Here it depends how long the values are stored there. So maybe it will be only possible through a modification of FM FM_ACCOUNT_DERIVE.

Depending on what you want to fill the extra field with keep in mind that USERDIM and the other account assignments are key fields in the line items and totals records. Each new value in the field creates its own entry in the totals item. A very large number of totals items can have a negative affect on system performance.

Best wishes

Felix

entry.title: Organizational Management in SAP S/4HANA HCM
entry.content:
Organizational Management in SAP S/4HANA

  • What is Organizational Management?

At its core, Organizational Management is the central module in SAP S/4HANA used to map your entire enterprise structure. It’s not just about creating an org chart; it's about building a dynamic, time-dependent model of your business that can be used for:

  • Analysis and Reporting: Gaining insights into your current organizational plan.
  • Workforce Planning: Simulating future structures and planning for reorganizations or expansions.
  • Process Automation: Driving workflows by ensuring tasks are routed to the right people in the right roles.
  • Integration: Serving as the foundational "blueprint" for a vast range of other SAP modules, including Human Experience Management (HXM), Financials (Controlling), Logistics, and more.

Think of OM as the digital skeleton of your company. Every department, team, role, and employee position is a bone, and the relationships between them allow the skeleton to function. A well-defined OM structure is the prerequisite for countless business processes.

  • From the Past to the Future: What's New in S/4HANA?

While the core concepts of OM remain timeless, the way we interact with them has evolved. This guide bridges the gap between the classic SAP ERP approach and the modern S/4HANA experience:

  • User Experience: We'll focus on intuitive SAP Fiori apps, which provide a modern, web-based interface for managing your org structure, replacing older transactions like "Organization and Staffing" (PPOME).
  • Real-Time Analytics: Leveraging the power of the HANA database, reporting on your org structure is faster and more powerful than ever.
  • Simplified Integration: S/4HANA provides a more streamlined integration between OM, HXM (the successor to HCM), and Finance.

Let's begin by exploring the fundamental concepts that make up your organizational blueprint.

  • Chapter 1: The Core Concepts of OM

To master Organizational Management, you first need to understand its unique, object-oriented design. Instead of static tables, OM uses a flexible network of individual objects and the relationships between them.

  • The Object-Oriented Approach 🧱

Every element in your organization is treated as a separate, self-contained

object with its own individual characteristics and data. These objects are then connected to each other through

relationships to form a dynamic network that mirrors your business reality.

  • Objects: These are the building blocks. Think of them as the nouns of your organization (e.g., a department, a job title, a specific person).
  • Relationships: These are the connections, or the verbs, that link objects together (e.g., a department incorporates a position, a position is held by a person).
  • Characteristics: These are the attributes or adjectives that describe an object, stored in data records called infotypes (e.g., the name of an org unit, the working hours for a position).

This model provides incredible flexibility to map complex structures, plan changes, and run detailed reports.

  • The Building Blocks: Core Object Types

While you can create custom object types, five basic types form the foundation of nearly every organizational plan. Each has a unique one-letter key.

  • 🏢Organizational Unit (Key: O)

An Organizational Unit describes the different business units in your company. These are typically structured hierarchically to form your departmental structure, like a family tree for your company.

  • Examples: Executive Board, Human Resources Department, Sales Team, Project Group.
  • Key Function: They group together positions and can be linked to financial entities like Cost Centers.
  • 🗂️ Job (Key: C)

A Job is a

general classification or template for responsibilities and tasks, not a specific role. Jobs are used to standardize roles across the company.

  • Examples: Manager, Consultant, Secretary, Engineer.
  • Key Function: They serve as templates for positions. A position inherits tasks, qualifications, and planned compensation from its describing Job, which significantly reduces data entry.
  • 👤Position (Key: S)

A Position is a

specific, individual instance of a Job within a particular Organizational Unit. Positions are the concrete "slots" that can be held by people.

  • Examples: "Manager of Sales, North America" (based on the "Manager" Job), "Secretary for Production Department" (based on the "Secretary" Job).
  • Key Function: Positions are the critical link between the organizational structure (OM) and the people (HXM). An employee is hired into a Position, not a Job. A position can be 100% filled, partially filled, or vacant.
  • 💰Cost Center (Key: K)

A Cost Center is an object that represents a location where costs are incurred. It's a fundamental object from the

Controlling (CO) module.

  • Examples: CC-SALES-NA (North American Sales), CC-HR-ADMIN.
  • Key Function: By linking Cost Centers to Organizational Units or Positions, you ensure that all personnel costs associated with those units are correctly allocated in your financial system. This is a primary point of integration between OM and Finance.
  • 🧑‍💼 Person (Key: P)

A Person represents an individual employee in your company who holds a position.

  • Examples: John Smith, Maria Garcia.
  • Key Function: While the Person object exists in OM, most of its detailed data (like address, salary, bank details) is maintained in the Human Experience Management (HXM) module. The link is made when a Person is assigned as the

holder of a Position.

  • Connecting the Dots: Key Relationships

Relationships are stored in a specific infotype (1001) and are reciprocal; defining one direction automatically creates the inverse. For example, if you state

Position A reports to Position B, the system automatically knows Position B is the line manager of Position A.

Here are some of the most critical relationships:

  • O is line manager of O (B002): Creates the hierarchy between organizational units.
  • O incorporates S (B003): Assigns a position to an organizational unit.
  • C describes S (A007): Links a position to its template Job.
  • S is holder P (B008): The most important relationship for integration, assigning an employee to a position.
  • O cost center assignment K (A011): Links an org unit to a cost center.
  • S manages O (A012): Designates a "chief position" or manager for an org unit.
  • The Big Picture: The Organizational Plan

When you combine these objects and relationships, you create your Organizational Plan. This is the complete, dynamic model of your enterprise structure. This plan can contain multiple structures:

  1. Organizational Structure: The hierarchy of organizational units.
  2. Reporting Structure: The hierarchy of positions showing who reports to whom.
  3. Staff Assignments: The complete picture of which positions belong to which org units and which people hold those positions.

To view these different structures, the system uses Evaluation Paths. An evaluation path is simply a predefined chain of relationships that tells the system how to navigate the network of objects to display a specific structure. For example, the

O-S-P evaluation path tells the system to start with an Org Unit (O), find all its Positions (S), and then find the People (P) holding those positions.

  • Chapter 2: Planning & Structuring Your Organization

A key strength of SAP's Organizational Management is its ability to manage your structure over time and simulate changes without impacting your live operations. This is achieved through a few core properties.

  • Time is Everything: Validity Periods ⏳

Every piece of data in OM—every object, every relationship, every characteristic—has a

start date and an end date. This validity period defines the lifespan of that data record.

This is incredibly powerful because it allows you to:

  • Maintain a full history: You can see exactly what your organization looked like on any date in the past.
  • Plan for the future: You can create new org units, positions, or relationships that will only become active on a future date. For example, you can build out the structure for a new department months before it officially opens.
  • Manage transitions smoothly: When a department is closed, you don't delete it. You delimit it by setting an end date. The data is preserved for historical reporting but is no longer active.
  • "What-If" Scenarios: Plan Versions 📋

Plan Versions are parallel universes for your organizational plan. They allow you to create and manage multiple, separate org plans simultaneously within the same system.

  • The 01 Current Plan: This is almost always the active, integrated plan version that your live business operations run on.
  • Planning Versions: You can create copies of the current plan to simulate different scenarios, such as an Acquisition Scenario or a Downsizing Scenario. You can model changes, analyze the impact, and plan costs in these "sandbox" versions without any risk to your live data.

Key Customizing Point: The active plan version is set in table T77S0 with the entry PLOGI PLOGI. This setting is foundational and should not be changed after go-live.

  • The Lifecycle of a Change: Plan Statuses ✅

Every data record (infotype) can go through a status cycle, which is especially useful for creating approval workflows. The primary statuses are:

  • Planned: A proposed change that is not yet active.
  • Submitted: Sent for approval.
  • Approved: Approved but not yet active.
  • Active: The change is live and operational in the system.
  • Rejected: A proposed change that was denied.

While you can use all statuses, many companies simplify the process and primarily use the

Active status for direct changes.

  • Automatic Data Flow: The Power of Inheritance

Inheritance is a key feature that promotes data consistency and reduces manual effort. When objects are linked in a hierarchy, attributes from higher-level objects can flow down to lower-level ones.

  • Cost Center Inheritance: If you assign a cost center to a high-level org unit (e.g., "Human Resources"), all subordinate org units ("Personnel Admin," "Talent Development") and their positions will automatically inherit that cost center, unless a more specific assignment is made at a lower level.
  • Job-to-Position Inheritance: When a position is created from a job, it inherits attributes like tasks, required qualifications, and planned compensation from the job.
  • Chapter 3: Maintaining the Organizational Plan

Now that we understand the concepts, let's explore the modern tools in SAP S/4HANA for creating, changing, and displaying your organizational plan.

  • The Modern Way: SAP Fiori Apps

For day-to-day maintenance, SAP Fiori provides a user-friendly, web-based experience. The primary app for this is Manage Organizational Structure (App ID: F5324). This app is the modern successor to the classic "Organization and Staffing" interface (PPOME/PPOCE).

With this app, you can:

  • Visually navigate your org structure in a tree format.
  • Create new organizational units and positions.
  • Assign positions to org units using simple drag-and-drop.
  • Assign employees (holders) to positions.
  • Delimit objects that are no longer needed.
  • Maintain the most important details (infotypes) for each object in a clear, tabbed layout.
  • Classic but Powerful: Expert Mode (SAP GUI)

For consultants and key users who need to perform detailed maintenance on specific object characteristics (infotypes), the classic SAP GUI "Expert Mode" is still an indispensable tool.

The main transaction code is PP01 - Maintain Object. From this single screen, you can:

  • Select any object by its type and ID.
  • See a list of all available infotypes for that object.
  • Create, change, display, copy, delimit, or delete any infotype record for the object.

This provides granular control over every piece of data in the OM module.

  • Key Infotypes in Detail

Here are some of the most commonly maintained infotypes you will work with, both in Fiori and the GUI:

  • Infotype 1000: Object: Defines the existence of an object, including its name and validity period. This is the first infotype created for any new object.
  • Infotype 1001: Relationships: The engine of OM. Every link between objects is a record in this infotype.
  • Infotype 1003: Department/Staff: An important flag for organizational units. The "Staff" checkbox indicates an advisory unit (like a board assistant) that sits outside the main hierarchy. The "Department" checkbox can be used for integration with Personnel Administration to define official departmental units.
  • Infotype 1007: Vacancy: This infotype explicitly flags a position as vacant and open for recruitment. This is crucial for integration with Recruiting modules. An occupied position can also be flagged as vacant if you know the holder is leaving in the future.
  • Infotype 1008: Account Assignment Features: This stores default values for Personnel Area, Personnel Subarea, and Business Area. These values are passed to an employee's record during hiring, ensuring consistency with Finance and HR policies.
  • Infotype 1011: Work Schedule: Defines the planned working hours for a position or org unit (e.g., 40 hours/week). This is used as a default value and for comparison when an employee's personal work schedule is defined in HXM.
  • Infotype 1018: Cost Distribution: Allows you to split the costs of a position or org unit across multiple cost centers or other financial objects (e.g., 70% to Cost Center A and 30% to Internal Order B).
  • Chapter 4: Integration with S/4HANA

Organizational Management does not exist in a vacuum. Its primary purpose is to provide a consistent structural foundation for other processes and modules.

  • Integration with Human Experience Management (HXM)

This is the most critical integration point. HXM (formerly Personnel Administration or PA) manages all data related to individual employees.

  • The Link: The integration is established when a Person (P) is assigned as the holder of a Position (S).
  • How it Works: When an employee is hired or transferred in HXM, the user selects the target position. The system then automatically reads the OM structure and populates the employee’s

Organizational Assignment (Infotype 0001) with the correct Org Unit, Job, and Cost Center from that position. If integration is active, these fields in the employee record become display-only, ensuring that the data can only originate from OM, guaranteeing consistency.

  • Integration with Financials (Controlling)

The link to finance is primarily through Cost Centers.

  • The Link: A Cost Center Assignment relationship (A011) is created between an Org Unit or Position and a Cost Center.
  • How it Works: When an employee is assigned to a position, they automatically inherit the position's cost center assignment. All payroll costs for that employee are then posted to that cost center in the financial ledger. The

Cost Distribution (Infotype 1018) allows for even more granular cost allocation.

  • Setting Up Integration: Key Steps

Activating integration is a critical configuration task performed by consultants. The core settings are managed in the Customizing table

T77S0.

  1. Set Active Plan Version: The entry PLOGI PLOGI must be set to 01 (or your active plan version). Without this, integration is off.
  2. Activate Main Integration Switch: The entry PLOGI ORGA must be set to X to enable the link between OM and HXM/PA objects.
  3. Run Initial Load Reports: To establish consistency between existing HXM/PA data and a new OM module (or vice-versa), SAP provides standard reports:
    • RHINTE00: Creates OM objects (Org Units, Positions, Jobs) based on data already existing in HXM employee records.
    • RHINTE10: Creates the necessary entries in HXM configuration tables for objects that were created first in OM.
    • RHINTE30: Updates the employee’s Organizational Assignment infotype (0001) with data from OM.
    • RHINTE20: A reconciliation report to check for inconsistencies between the two modules.
  • Chapter 5: Business Case & Test Plan

Let's apply these concepts in a practical, end-to-end business scenario.

  • 🏢Business Scenario: Global Innovations Inc.

Global Innovations Inc. is a growing technology firm. They are restructuring their Human Resources department to better support their global workforce. They need to create a new "Global HR" organizational unit, define new roles, create positions, and hire an employee into one of the new roles.

This test plan will guide you through building this structure from scratch.

  • Test Plan: Restructuring the HR Department

Objective: To correctly model the new HR structure in SAP S/4HANA, create positions, and hire an employee, ensuring data flows correctly through integrated systems.

  • Part 1: Master Data Prerequisites

Before building the structure, we need the foundational master data.

Exercise 1.1: Create Cost Centers

  • App: Manage Cost Centers (Fiori App ID F1563) or SAP GUI KS01.
  • Task: Create two new cost centers for the fiscal year.
    • HR-ADMIN-##: HR Administration - Group ##
    • HR-TALENT-##: Talent Development - Group ##
    • (Replace ## with your assigned group number, e.g., 01).

Exercise 1.2: Create Jobs

  • App: Manage Job Descriptions (Fiori) or SAP GUI PO03 / PP01.
  • Task: Create the following general Jobs that will be used as templates.
    • HR_MGR_##: HR Manager - Group ##
    • HR_ADMIN_##: HR Administrator - Group ##
    • TAL_SPEC_##: Talent Specialist - Group ##
  • Part 2: Building the Organizational Structure

Now we will use the core OM maintenance tools to build the org plan.

Exercise 2.1: Create the New "Global HR" Structure

  • App: Manage Organizational Structure (Fiori App ID F5324).
  • Task: Create the main organizational units.
    1. Create a new root organizational unit called

Global HR - ##.

    1. In the details section for this org unit, go to the

Account Assignment tab and assign the Cost Center HR-ADMIN-## as the master cost center.

    1. Select the

Global HR - ## unit, and create two subordinate org units underneath it:

      • Personnel Admin - ##
      • Talent Development - ##
    1. Select the Talent Development - ## unit and assign it the specific Cost Center HR-TALENT-##. This will override the inherited cost center for this specific branch of the structure.
    2. Save your changes.

Exercise 2.2: Create Positions within the Structure

  • App: Manage Organizational Structure (Fiori).
  • Task: Create the specific positions (the "slots" for employees) within your new org units.
    1. Select the Talent Development - ## org unit.
    2. Create a new position within it named Head of Talent Dev - ##.
    3. In the position's details, link it to the

HR_MGR_## Job you created earlier.

    1. Select the Personnel Admin - ## org unit.
    2. Create a new position named PA Administrator - ##.
    3. Link this position to the HR_ADMIN_## Job.
    4. Save your changes. You now have an organizational structure with defined, vacant positions.

Exercise 2.3: Hire an Employee (HXM Integration)

  • App: Manage Workforce (Fiori) or SAP GUI PA40 (Personnel Actions).
  • Task: Hire a new employee into the PA Administrator - ## position and observe the data integration.
    1. Start the "Hiring" action for a new employee.
    2. In the initial screen, enter the

Start Date and specify the Position Number for PA Administrator - ##.

    1. Press Enter.

Observe the results: The system should automatically propose values for Personnel Area, Employee Group, and Employee Subgroup based on settings inherited from the position and its org unit.

    1. Proceed to the Organizational Assignment screen (Infotype 0001).
    2. Observe the results: The fields for Organizational Unit, Job, and Cost Center should be filled automatically and greyed out (display-only). This confirms that integration is active and data is flowing correctly from your OM structure.
    3. Complete the hiring process by entering the required personal data.
  • Part 3: Reporting and Analysis

Finally, let's use reporting tools to view and validate our new structure.

Exercise 3.1: View the Organizational Chart

  • App: Display Organizational Structure (Fiori).
  • Task: View the structure you built.
    1. Search for your root organizational unit, Global HR - ##.
    2. The app will display the hierarchy, showing the org units, the positions within them, and the name of the employee you just hired as the holder of the

PA Administrator - ## position.

Exercise 3.2: Find Vacant Positions

  • App: SAP GUI Report S_AHR_61016502 - Vacant Positions.
  • Task: Run a report to find all positions that are not yet filled.
    1. Enter your root organizational unit Global HR - ## as the object to be evaluated.
    2. Execute the report.
    3. The result list should show the position Head of Talent Dev - ## as vacant, while the PA Administrator - ## position should not appear on this list because it is now occupied.

Congratulations! You have successfully completed an end-to-end process in Organizational Management, from master data creation and structure building to hiring an employee and running reports.

 

  • Chapter 6: Advanced Organizational Structures

While a standard hierarchy meets the needs of many companies, modern enterprises often require more complex structures to manage projects, product lines, or regional responsibilities. SAP Organizational Management provides powerful tools to model these advanced scenarios.

  • Matrix Organizations: The Two-Boss System 🌐

A

matrix organization is a structure where employees have multiple reporting lines. For instance, a software developer might report to their functional line manager (e.g., "Head of Engineering") and simultaneously to a specific project manager (e.g., "Project Alpha Lead"). This creates a two-dimensional, or matrix, chain of command.

SAP provides a dedicated interface to manage these structures.

  • Concept: The matrix view maps the objects from one structure (e.g., the standard organizational hierarchy) against the objects of a second structure (e.g., a project structure). You can then create relationships between objects from the two dimensions.
  • SAP S/4HANA Tool: The classic interface for this is Matrix Maintenance (SAP GUI transaction PPME).
  • How it Works:
    1. You define

Dimension 1, typically your standard org structure, by selecting a root object (like an org unit) and an evaluation path (like O-S-P to show all people).

    1. You define

Dimension 2, the second structure, such as a project team hierarchy.

    1. The interface displays a grid. You can then create a new relationship (e.g., "is a member of project team") simply by clicking the intersection between an employee from Dimension 1 and a project team from Dimension 2.

Customizing Point: The types of matrices you can create are defined in Customizing, where you specify the object types, evaluation paths for each dimension, and the relationship type that connects the two dimensions.

  • General Structures: The All-Purpose Tool 🛠️

What if you need to model a structure that doesn't fit a standard view, perhaps involving custom object types? The General Structures interface (SAP GUI transaction PPST) is the answer.

This highly flexible tool allows you to display and maintain

any structure in your system, provided you can define it with an evaluation path. It's particularly useful for:

  • Mapping corporate legal structures (e.g., holding companies and their subsidiaries).
  • Visualizing relationships between non-standard or custom object types.
  • Performing maintenance on relationships that aren't available in the standard Fiori apps.

Using it is simple: you provide a starting object, an evaluation path, and a time period, and the system displays the resulting structure in a tree format, ready for maintenance.

  • Chapter 7: Empowering Managers with Self-Service

In a modern enterprise, HR processes are no longer confined to the HR department. Line managers are increasingly responsible for administrative and strategic tasks related to their teams. SAP S/4HANA empowers them through

Manager Self-Service (MSS), a collection of Fiori apps designed specifically for managers.

MSS is the modern, portal-based successor to the classic "Manager's Desktop". It provides a single point of entry for managers to access information and initiate processes for their area of responsibility.

  • Prerequisites for MSS

For MSS to work, a correctly maintained OM structure is absolutely essential. The system identifies a manager's team using specific relationships:

  1. The manager must hold a

Position.

  1. That Position must be designated as the

chief position of an Organizational Unit (using the manages A/B012 relationship).

  1. The manager's employee record must be linked to their system

User ID (in Infotype 0105, subtype 0001).

When the manager logs in, the system reads this structure to determine which employees and org units fall under their responsibility.

  • Common MSS Functions

MSS provides managers with a suite of apps to handle a wide range of tasks, streamlining processes and reducing the burden on HR.

  • Team Management:
    • View detailed employee profiles and org charts for their team.
    • Access contact information and view team calendars for leave and travel.
  • Compensation & Budgeting:
    • Initiate compensation changes like salary adjustments or bonuses.
    • Monitor budgets and compare planned vs. actual personnel costs.
  • Recruitment & Staffing:
    • Request to open a new position.
    • View applicants and participate in the hiring process.
  • Organizational Changes:
    • Initiate an

organizational reassignment for an employee, such as a transfer to a new position or a change of reporting line.

  • Approvals (Workflow Integration):
    • Approve requests submitted by employees via

Employee Self-Service (ESS), such as leave requests, travel expenses, and timesheet entries.

When a manager initiates a process like a transfer or a pay raise, it typically triggers an SAP Business Workflow. The request is stored as a plan and routed to the responsible HR administrator's inbox for review, validation, and final execution. This ensures that while managers are empowered to act, proper governance and HR oversight are maintained.

  • Chapter 8: In-Depth Reporting and Analytics

A well-maintained organizational plan is a goldmine of data. SAP S/4HANA provides a suite of standard reports to help you analyze your structure, audit your data, and answer critical business questions.

Reporting in OM is primarily based on the Logical Database PCH, a technical framework designed specifically for reading the complex, networked data of the organizational plan.

  • Understanding the Standard Selection Screen

Most OM reports share a standard selection screen that allows you to precisely define the data you want to see. The key parameters are:

  • Plan Version: Specifies which plan version to report on (e.g., the 01 Current Plan).
  • Object Type / ID: Allows you to start the report for one or more specific objects (e.g., your company's root org unit).
  • Evaluation Path: This is the most important parameter for structural reports. It tells the system

how to navigate the structure from your starting object. For example, using the

O-S-P path will show org units, their positions, and the employees in them.

  • Reporting Period: Defines the key date or period for which the data should be valid, allowing you to run historical reports.
  • Display Depth: Limits how many levels of the hierarchy the report will show.
  • Key Standard Reports

You can find these reports in the SAP Easy Access menu under Human Resources → Organizational Management → Info System.

  • Structure Display / Maintenance (RHSTRU00): This is the fundamental structural report. It provides a technical, tree-based view of any structure based on a starting object and an evaluation path. It's excellent for troubleshooting and validating relationships.
  • Organizational Structure with Persons: A user-friendly report that displays the organizational chart with the names of the employees holding each position.
  • Vacant Positions: A critical report for recruitment that lists all positions within a given structure that are not currently occupied.
  • Existing Objects (e.g., Existing Jobs): Sequential reports that provide a list of all objects of a certain type, allowing you to audit your master data.
  • Structural Graphics: This classic tool displays the organizational plan as a graphical chart. While still available, many modern Fiori apps now embed similar visualizations directly.
  • HR Master Data Reporting via OM Structures (RHPNPSUP): A powerful integration report. It first reads the OM structure to gather a list of employees (personnel numbers) and then runs a standard HXM/PA report (like a salary list) for just that group of people.
  • Conclusion

You now have a comprehensive understanding of Organizational Management in SAP S/4HANA, from its core object-oriented concepts to the modern Fiori apps used to maintain it.

Remember, OM is more than just a module; it is the foundational blueprint of your enterprise within SAP. A clean, accurate, and well-maintained organizational plan is the prerequisite for seamless integration, efficient workflows, empowered managers, and insightful reporting across your entire S/4HANA landscape. By mastering these principles, you are not just managing data—you are building the digital framework for your company's success.

  • Appendix 1: Data Used in Exercises

This data is provided for use in the training exercises outlined in this guide.
